Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Photochemically-Induced Nucleation and Growth of Manganese Oxides at Environmental Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Science Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Young-Shin Jun of Washington University in St. Louis examines changes in manganese compounds on exposure to the environment. The natural abundance of manganese is a primary motivation for studying its roles in natural and man-made environmental processes. Many manganese-contaminated lands result from human activities (e. g., acid mine drainage and contamination from urban atmospheres). Understanding the changes in various manganese-containing species on exposure to the environment is crucial to controlling manganese concentrations in drinking water. With support from Washington University's Institute for School Partnership (ISP), Professor Jun develops an "Environmental Chemistry and Energy" themed lecture series, with experimental chemistry and computer modeling experiments. Professor Jun's research findings are incorporated into university courses in Environmental Nanochemistry and Aquatic Chemistry. These educational activities provide development opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. The educational activities are evaluated periodically by faculty from the ISP.

The rich redox reactivity of manganese is of interest in engineered systems, such as in batteries and catalyzed water oxidation. This project provides fundamental thermodynamic and kinetic information about manganese (Mn) oxidation and subsequent manganese oxide (delta-MnO2) nanosheet nucleation and growth. The research project utilizes multidisciplinary tools to investigate the early stages of delta MnO2 nanosheet nucleation and in situ growth at the molecular scale. Small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS) / grazing incidence SAXS provides real-time information. Changes in mineral phases and mineral morphologies are studied with various X-ray techniques and electron microscopies. Fluid chemistry and electrochemical measurements are also be made. Furthermore, the synthesized delta-MnO2 is tested for its applications as an effective, environmentally-abundant cathode in a lithium-ion battery. This project provides useful information for developing sustainable energy materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photochemically-Induced Nucleation and Growth of Manganese Oxides at Environmental Interfaces. Prof. Young-Shin Jun received an NSF grant (CHE-1610728) for investigating fast Mn oxidation from Mn2+ to Mn(IV) by nitrate photolysis in sunlight.

Understanding the redox chemistry of manganese is crucial to elucidating the biogeochemical cycling of metal and organic carbon and the fate of contaminants and nutrients in aqueous systems. The redox reactivity of manganese is also of interest in engineering applications, such as batteries and catalysts for water oxidation. For many decades, fast oxidation from Mn2+ to Mn(IV) has been reported only in microbially-promoted systems. In this project, for the first time, we examined fast Mn oxidation from Mn2+ to Mn(IV) by nitrate photolysis in sunlight.

Intellectual Merit: We showed how nitrate, a naturally abundant anion, can oxidize Mn2+ (aq) to Mn(IV) through two steps of one-electron transfer, and we further showed that the process occurred at a rate comparable to that of biotic Mn oxidation. Using a multidisciplinary approach, we provided new thermodynamic and kinetic information about nucleation of Mn oxide nanosheets. In particular, using strong Mn(III)-pyrophosphate (PP) complexes, the team investigated the role of ligands in Mn oxidation and δ-MnO2 nanosheets nucleation. In the presence of different PP concentration, they observed changes in layer stacking behaviors, and structural symmetry changes from hexagonal to orthogonal. Key accomplishments of this project include:

(1)   We discovered the influence of sunlight on Mn oxidation in nitrate solutions, and the kinetics and mechanisms of Mn(IV) oxide nucleation and growth.

(2)   We enhanced layered δ-MnO2 nanosheet formation rates, using pyrophosphate.

(3)   We controlled δ-MnO2 layer thickness and studied its quantum confinement effects. 

(4)   We explained how a variety of abiotically formed Mn(IV) oxides, such as todorokite and birnessite, can form via incorporation of cations, such as Na+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Co2+.

(5)   We investigated H+-Li+ ion-exchange in the synthesized δ-MnO2 nanosheets, and tested the electronic properties of Li+-δ-MnO2 (LiMnO2) for potential utilization as a Li-ion battery.

This project has resulted in one doctoral dissertation and one patent application. The project outcomes were disseminated via five journal articles, with three more papers currently in preparation, and two invited and 16 contributed presentations at universities and conferences. To conduct the research, we made successful proposals for nine synchrotron-based X-ray beamtime allocations at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory, IL.

Broader Impacts: To design the properties of inorganic catalysts in environmentally-friendly ways, many scientists are inspired by nature, the most successful sustainable system. Environmental chemistry and materials science offer numerous junctions for the development of sustainable chemistry. This project highlighted the critical role of a photochemically-assisted abiotic inorganic process in Mn oxidation and the consequent formation of disordered δ-MnO2 in a nitrate solution. The findings provided useful information about how to synthesize disordered δ-MnO2 nanostructures and tune their oxidation state and structural properties in an environmentally-friendly way. The project team also found that how tunnel-structured MnO2 forms that can be used for energy storage materials.

As an outreach to the broader regional community, we designed a lecture on energy and the environment for Washington University's Institute for School Partnership and Washington University's College Prep program. The research findings were also incorporated into Aquatic Chemistry classes as examples of metal complexation, dissolution and precipitation, and redox chemistry. They were also incorporated in Environmental NanoChemistry classes as examples of two-dimensional nanostructures and sustainable nanomaterials synthesis. The project has supported four doctoral students and three undergraduate student researchers (one woman and two African American students) in the PI's lab, who gained hands-on experience studying manganese oxide synthesis. Three of the students are now attending doctoral programs at Caltech, the University of Texas-Austin, and the University of South Florida, and a doctoral student who worked on this project has become a professor at Changwon National University in South Korea.
